urn:contentItem:5DKR-6V81-JD6G-449X-00000-00Council must retain dam to fight fires2014-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisLETTERSCouncil must retain dam to fight fires

I CHECKED out the Rural Fire Service Fire information page.

It listed 49 bushfires currently burning in NSW.

The dry sclerophyll forests of Australia which make up so much of our bushland are adapted to fire.

Couple that with a strong wind and it's obvious how a forest fire can quickly spread.

Armidale has a lot of dry sclerophyll woodland to the west and north west.

It is vital that Armidale retain as many large bodies of water as possible.

Dumaresq Dam is an ideal source of water for helicopters as it still contains a fair bit of water even after all the farm dams have dried up, as is the current situation.

It is also close to the airport and the town.

For this reason it is imperative that we retain Dumaresq Dam at the current height of the dam wall.

Maria Hitchcock

Armidale

AN ISRAELI tourist, 23, has been detained on suspicion of causing a forest fire that has burned more than 11,000ha in the Torres de Paine national park.

Regional prosecutor Juan Melendez identified the man as Roter Singer, though Israel Radio gave the first name as Rotem. Mr Melendez said the man had acknowledged a part in negligently allowing the fire to start.

Girls mistreated Boko Haram hostages were held in atrocious conditions in the group's Sambisa Forest stronghold, Nigeria's military has said after nearly 500 women and girls were released this week.

"The important thing is that Nigerians held captive under very severe and inhuman conditions have been freed," spokesman Chris Olukolade said yesterday.

Fires almost out Firefighters have nearly extinguished a forest fire near Ukraine's Chernobyl plant, the scene of the world's worst nuclear accident in 1986. "There are no more open flames," said the deputy head of the emergencies ministry, Mykola Chechetkin.

Church sells assets The Church of England is to sell off investments in coal and tar sands to try to help curb climate change.

The divestment from coal burnt for energy and oil from tar sands, among the most polluting fossil fuels, is a victory for campaigners urging institutions to pull out of such investments.

Prince wants a girlPrince Charles has revealed he's hoping for a granddaughter as the British royal family eagerly await the birth of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's second child.

urn:contentItem:57F8-7T41-JC0X-K449-00000-00ACT:Firecrews battle remote ACT bushfire2013-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSACT:Firecrews battle remote ACT bushfireCANBERRA Jan 6

  The ACT Rural Fire Service is working to extinguish a forest fire burning in the far southwest region of the Namadgi National Park.
   The bushfire alert and warning level for the fire has been set at "advice".
   The ACT Rural Fire Service has a waterbombing aircraft on scene and two additional aircraft carrying remote area fire teams who are preparing to winch into the location.
   The remote fire is located near Sentry Box Mountain and is not threatening any property.
   At the current fire danger level of low to moderate, the fire is burning at a slow rate and should be easily controlled.

urn:contentItem:58T9-WFB1-JD3N-51B3-00000-00Investigators arrive to look at fire tragedy2013-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 23Investigators arrive to look at fire tragedy

INVESTIGATORS from across the US have poured into an Arizona town to learn why 19 elite firefighters died in an out-of-control wildfire and whether human error played a role.

The investigation into the country's biggest loss of firefighters since September 11, 2001, will look at whether the crew paid attention to the forecast, created an escape route, and took other precautions developed after a similar disaster in Colorado nearly two decades ago.

The team will also look at whether the crew should have been withdrawn before the fire exploded.

Within hours on Sunday, violent wind gusts turned what was believed to be a relatively manageable, lightning-ignited forest fire into a death trap.

A PAGE was sent out to local CFS crews to help fight the Wirrabara Forest fire on Thursday, but was later cancelled because of local farming commitments.

CFS Region 6 acting regional commander Justin Woolford said the request had been cancelled due to the rain Eyre Peninsula had a lot of farmer volunteers seeding.

About 120 firefighters from the CFS, Department of Environment and Natural Resources and ForestrySA with support from fire fighting aircraft were used to contain the bushfire on Saturday after it burnt about 800 hectares.

urn:contentItem:57RW-WWK1-JD3N-53BY-00000-00Huge blaze puts Chile city on red alert2013-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 32Huge blaze puts Chile city on red alert

CHILE'S emergency office has issued a red alert after a fire broke out in the coastal city of Valparaiso.

The ONEMI says the forest fire on the city's San Roque hill has consumed 60 homes and forced the evacuation of about 500 families.

Fifteen people were being treated for minor injuries, Guillermo de la Maza, the ONEMI's Valparaiso regional director, said yesterday.

Police say they have arrested at least three people for looting.

The fire began in the Rodelio area and forced the closure of Route 68, which connects Valparaiso to the Chilean capital, Santiago. More than a dozen firefighter units were yesterday battling the blaze.

TWO pilots were confirmed dead yesterday in the crash of a Canadian water-bombing plane that was fighting a forest fire.

The wildfire and steep terrain kept rescue workers from reaching the crash site after the plane went down about 160km northeast of Vancouver.

The Conair plane was chartered by the provincial government to battle the fires.

urn:contentItem:5B52-HMN1-F0J6-J2M1-00000-00THE weather gods have both helped and hindered firefighters2013-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 2THE weather gods have both helped and hindered firefighters

THE weather gods have both helped and hindered firefighters trying to contain two bush fires burning in the region.

The rain of recent days has helped to almost extinguish a forest fire at Reedy Creek, south-east of Armidale, that burnt out 420 hectares.

But firefighters will be keeping an eye on a fire at Mummel Gulf near Walcha over the weekend after a number of lightning strikes hit the area.

NSW Rural Fire Service duty officer Mike Petrov said although the fire was well under control, it would be monitored to ensure it did not flare and break containment lines.

Meanwhile, a scrub fire at Nullamanna Road north-east of Inverell that has burnt 4831 hectares remains under control, as is a small fire that destroyed 24 hectares of forest at Ogunbil south-east of Tamworth.

urn:contentItem:54MM-MX01-JD3N-51HV-00000-00Killer fire in Chile2012-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisFOREIGNPg. 27Killer fire in Chile

SANTIAGO: A new forest fire has claimed one life in southern Chile just hours after firefighters tamed a massive blaze that consumed 13,000ha in Patagonia.

The new inferno has consumed about 8000ha in the commune of Quillon, in southern Chile's Biobio region. Five active forest fires had destroyed at least 30 homes, officials said.

A 75-year-old man who rejected warnings to leave his home died yesterday.

Earlier, President Sebastian Pinera announced several hundred firefighters had extinguished a five-day-old inferno in Torres del Paine National Park.

urn:contentItem:59YY-79B1-F0J6-J2SJ-00000-00FIRE crews remained on-scene overnight to try to contain2013-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisFRONPg. 1FIRE crews remained on-scene overnight to try to containNADINE MORTON

FIRE crews remained on-scene overnight to try to contain a 15-hectare forest fire burning near isolated farm properties north of Orange.

The fire broke out mid-afternoon in a privately-owned pine plantation at the end of Bevan Road at Mullion Creek.

Yesterday afternoon's hot, windy weather had firefighters scrambling to contain the blaze.

By 5.30pm yesterday, spot fires had started to the east of containment lines.

The five-hectare fire had also tripled in size to 15 hectares.

The dense pine plantation proved difficult for firefighters and their trucks to access so a water bombing helicopter was brought in late yesterday to tackle the blaze from above.

NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) Canobolas Zone duty officer Brett Bowden said there were no properties under threat late yesterday.

"The nearest house is two kilometres to the north," he said.

urn:contentItem:5F76-S9J1-F0J6-J27G-00000-00Plenty of enquiries in SE2015-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 13Plenty of enquiries in SE

COUNTRY Fire Service Region Five commander John Probert said the South East had seen plenty of enquiries from potential firefighters, particularly around the Wattle Range and Mount Gambier districts.

At the beginning of January, a large forest fire blazed for two days under catastrophic conditions before being contained.

John said enquiries had lifted after that blaze, and some other smaller fires across the region.

"It's not been enormous numbers but we're certainly seeing a few more each week," he said.

"People become more aware of fires and what they can do."

The impact was not limited to the Mount Gambier region, with Naracoorte also seeing a lift in potential volunteer numbers while anecdotally, other brigades seem to be seeing the same trend.

"We are always looking for more volunteers," John said.

"The rural brigades do suffer more than the peri-urban areas."

He said anyone considering volunteering with their CFS should approach their brigade captain in the first instance.

"It's a very worthwhile thing," he said.

"You get good training and good equipment and you are providing a worthwhile service to the community."

ELIZABETH ANDERSON

urn:contentItem:59T6-7CD1-F12F-F2FH-00000-00QUEENSLAND FIRE AND EMERGENCY SERVICES CONTINUE TO BACKBURN AROUND TUAN TOWNSHIP2013-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisQUEENSLAND FIRE AND EMERGENCY SERVICES CONTINUE TO BACKBURN AROUND TUAN TOWNSHIP

BRISBANE, Queensland, Nov. 10 -- The Queensland Department of Community Safety issued the following news release:

Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) are continuing to backburn around the Tuan Township, south of Maryborough. Residents and visitors are asked to avoid the areas in Big Tuan, Little Tuan and Tuan where emergency crews are operating. This grass and forest fire, which they are still working to contain, is located in forestry area near Cooloola Coast and Boonooroo roads but is slowly moving towards the Tuan township. It started just before midday yesterday and there is no immediate threat to homes. A smoke hazard continues to affect the area and residents who suffer from respiratory conditions should take the necessary precautions. Residents should keep their doors and windows closed and motorists should drive to conditions. FACTOR 4

Paul Mason

A & C Black Publishers Ltd, $14.99

If you like action-packed books, this book is the one for you . . . especially if you love explosions and mysteries.

Four friends are on a school science trip when something very strange happens.

They get caught in some mysterious gas, which causes them to change in a way that lets them have control over the powers of nature. One adventure involves a forest fire and using strange equipment.

This is a chapter book with only a few illustrations.

I would recommend this book for children in year 3 who are advanced readers.

This is the first book in the series called Factor 4.

I am really looking forward to reading the next book in the series, which will be called Tiger Tiger. I hope you will be too.

JAMESON LYONS, year 6

St Pius X Primary School

Started: 3.15pm

Injuries: Two Bald Hills residents were taken to Ballarat Base Hospital for treatment.

urn:contentItem:5B8G-2J51-JD34-V4B7-00000-00THE Rural Fire Service and National Parks and Wildlife2014-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisP2LOPg. 2THE Rural Fire Service and National Parks and Wildlife

THE Rural Fire Service and National Parks and Wildlife Service were working hard to contain a forest fire burning in Turon National Park yesterday afternoon.

Seven RFS trucks, two National Parks vehicles and two helicopters attended a blaze burning some four kilometres west of Ben Bullen.

RFS Chifley/Lithgow team manager Superintendent Tom Shirt said the Wool Shed Flat fire started shortly before midday yesterday.

"It started in a camping area and progressed uphill into some really rugged country," he said.

"At this stage crews are working at what they can.

"National Parks will be bringing in remote area fire fighters to help."

Supt Shirt said the fire had burnt through around five hectares of Turon National Park.

He said he expected crews would battle the blaze well into the night and noted that heavy plant and earthmoving machinery would be brought in to put in containment lines.

Supt Shirt said an investigation would be carried out to determine the cause of the fire.

urn:contentItem:5D7N-XV31-JCBD-B31V-00000-00WEDNESDAY2014-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisAPg. C012WEDNESDAYThe Canberra Times

WEDNESDAY A Night at the Movies: Stephen King TCM, 8.30pm Stephen King is a thoughtful, perceptive and opinionated viewer of horror movies. And, of course, one who is uncommonly well-placed to critique them, given the many decades that he has been analysing them, writing stories that get turned into them, and appearing in them himself.

This fascinating special begins with King revealing that the first movie to terrify him was Bambi (yes, it was the forest fire). Then we're into the first horror movies to make an impact on him (Francis Ford Coppola's Dementia 13 and George Romero's Night of the Living Dead), and his own experience in the horror movie business. King talks about his enlightening first viewing of Carrie in a black cinema, his well- documented disappointment with Stanley Kubrick's The Shining ("A beautiful car with no engine"), and his opinion that Dee Wallace should have won an Oscar for Cujo. Just as interesting are his problems with werewolves (too literal a transformation), vampires (he doesn't buy the male ones as suave seducers) and the slasher genre (misogyny, misanthropy), and his admiration of Tobe Hooper and the makers of The Blair WitchProject.

TWO pilots were confirmed dead on Sunday in the crash of a Canadian waterbombing plane that was fighting a forest fire.

The wildfire and steep terrain kept rescue workers from reaching the crash site after the plane went down on Saturday night about 160 kilometres northeast of Vancouver.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police confirmed the deaths, and said the plane was badly damaged after it crashed and burst into flames.

``Witnesses reported seeing the plane drop from the sky and seeing it crash,'' said a spokesman.

urn:contentItem:5BNS-KNY1-F0NH-V027-00000-00Green Cape hazard reduction update2014-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisFRONTPAGEGreen Cape hazard reduction update

Hazard reduction burning in the Green Cape area of Ben Boyd National Park has spread beyond containment lines but property, including the Light Station, is not at risk, NPWS has said.

"Eden and other communities to the north of Green Cape may experience smoke this afternoon or evening if the predicted southerly change eventuates.

"The Light to Light walking track from Bittangabee Bay to Green Cape is closed to the public at this time, however Bittangabee campground and all other formal camping areas remain open at this stage," the NPWS spokeswoman said.

"The road to Green Cape is closed from the Bittangabee turnoff while NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Rural Fire Service manage the fire, however it will re-open as soon as is safely possible."

This road closure means the fishing vantages of Pulpit Rock and City Rock are not accessible while crews are working in the region.

The Rural Fire Service reported at 9.15am Wednesday, March 5, that a forest fire covering 230 ha, at Pulpit Rock, Green Cape was being controlled.

urn:contentItem:596Y-PWX1-JD3N-50JF-00000-00Wyong firies in forest training2013-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19Wyong firies in forest training

A TWO-day fire fighting exercise in Bulahdelah State Forest saw Wyong firies attend scenarios for training purposes recently.

Forestry Corporation (formerly Forests NSW) organised the recent practice days. About 100 staff members participated in six different scenarios including extinguishing car fires and first aid treatment to prepare for the fire season, which starts on October 1.

Forestry Corporation Fire training co-ordinator Cameron Wade said the annual preseason fire days were part of ongoing training for all of the State's 400 forest fire fighters and Bulahdelah was the second stop on a 12-week training tour throughout NSW.

"These fire training days are a yearly event focusing on firefighter safety, community safety and asset protection," Mr Wade said.

"With good rains and subsequent growth during the past year, this fire season has the potential to be very challenging.""Local RFS volunteers assisted in the training days as part of the State's co- ordinated fire fighting effort."

TCM, 8.30pm

Stephen King is a thoughtful, perceptive and opinionated viewer of horror movies. And, of course, one who is uncommonly well-placed to critique them, given the many decades that he has been analysing them, writing stories that get turned into them, and appearing in them himself. This fascinating special begins with King revealing that the first movie to terrify him was Bambi (yes, it was the forest fire). King talks about his enlightening first viewing of Carrie in a black cinema, his well-documented disappointment with Stanley Kubrick's The Shining ("A beautiful car with no engine"), and his opinion that Dee Wallace should have won an Oscar for Cujo.   Tens of thousands of hectares of state forest in southeast Queensland have been destroyed by a massive bushfire.
   Firefighters on Saturday battled 35 blazes across the state, some of which have been burning for a week.


   The Department of Community Safety (DCS) said about 70,000 hectares of state forest southwest of Gayndah had been destroyed by fire.
   A large bushfire has been burning since last week in inaccessible land in the Allies Creek State Forest.
   Fire crews were working with landowners to strengthen containment lines and protect pastures, the DCS said.
   Meanwhile large bushfires continue to burn northeast of Toowoomba at Ravensbourne National Park.
   The slow-moving fires were started by lightning strikes last Saturday.
   In the northwest, crews are grappling with a grassfire with a front up to 20km long.
   The blaze is burning at Three Rivers, north of Cloncurry.
   None of the fires are directly threatening properties.

urn:contentItem:5BPV-CHB1-F0J6-J0R8-00000-00Planned burns ready to go2014-03-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisERPPg. 7Planned burns ready to goCARLY WERNER

THE Department of Environment and Primary Industries will ignite planned burns to reduce fuels on public land in the next few weeks.

The department's chief fire officer, Alan Goodwin, said the group was committed to implementing an increased planned burning program as recommended by the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission.

"Our specialist forest fire-fighters have been working hard to fight fires over the summer, but now as temperatures drop our attention will turn to planned burns to reduce bushfire risk to people, communities and the environment," he said. "This summer we have seen fires that have started in remote areas such as the Mallee and far east Gippsland and have continued to burn for weeks. This is why planned burning will target not just burns close to towns, but also remote area burns."

Mr Goodwin said reducing fuel loads on public land both in remote areas and close to properties and towns helped slow the spread and intensity of bushfires, making them easier to control.

Mr Goodwin said people could visit www.depi.vic.gov.au/burnsmap or call 1800 240 667 for more information.

I AM sick to my stomach as I continue to read about arson attacks.

State and federal governments must change the law on arson, whether it be a brushfence set alight or a forest fire.

BETTY LYNNE DENTON, Para Hills West.

urn:contentItem:5B64-CPK1-JD34-V3KG-00000-00FIRE investigators were called to a blaze that started2014-01-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 5FIRE investigators were called to a blaze that started

FIRE investigators were called to a blaze that started north-west of Orange at Baldry early on New Year's Day.

NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) crews were called to a fire at Yeoville Road at 1.30am yesterday.

Canobolas Zone duty officer Arthur Sharp said multiple tankers were called out to the one-hectare fire, which was started along a roadside.

"There were a lot of trees burning so we had to cut some down," he said.

Mr Sharp said winds blew smoke over Orange yesterday from multiple fires burning across the state.

"Prevailing winds are blowing smoke in from other regions," he said.

Mr Sharp said he had received phone calls about the smoke not just from Orange residents but people further afield.

"I've taken calls from people in Woodstock, Molong and Gooloogong," he said.

Other central west fires include a 40-hectare forest fire at the base of the Oberon Mount, which is listed by the NSWRFS as under control.

A 70-hectare grass fire at Tanks Road, Parkes is now under control.

The haystack fire at Heath Road, Eurimbla in the Wellington council is also now under control.

- Nadine Morton

urn:contentItem:51MS-YJ41-F0JP-W37W-00000-00Israeli fire inspires unity2010-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisSUNDAY WORLDPg. 13Israeli fire inspires unity

HAIFA, Israel: Responding to an Israeli distress call, aircraft from Turkey, Greece, Cyprus and Britain dumped sea water and flame retardant on a woodland inferno that has killed dozens, displaced thousands and ravaged a prized forest.

As the country mourned the dead, Israelis long known for their high-tech society and vaunted rescue missions abroad were stunned on Friday at their firefighters' helplessness in quelling the blaze, the worst forest fire in the nation's history.

Still, for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu embattled over the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace effort it was also a chance to show that Israel was perhaps not so isolated after all. Even the Palestinian Authority pitched in with firefighting units.

urn:contentItem:56SG-N0J1-DYG0-9363-00000-00VIC:Alan Goodwin new Vic fire chief2012-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Alan Goodwin new Vic fire chiefMELBOURNE Oct 10

  Alan Goodwin is Victoria's new chief fire officer responsible for fire management and prevention on public land.
   Mr Goodwin is currently managing the Department of Sustainability and Environment's (DSE) north-west region and has more than 20 years' experience in the forest fire industry.


   He will be the DSE's chief fire officer from November 1 and replaces Ewan Waller, who did not seek reappointment.
   Mr Waller was criticised by the bushfires royal commission and was the last remaining fire chief from the 2009 Black Saturday tragedy.
   Environment Minister Ryan Smith said Mr Goodwin had been involved in deployments to Canada and the United States.
   "Alan's background stands him in good stead to lead DSE's fuel reduction program, which includes planned burning, to reduce bushfire risk to human life, communities, essential and community infrastructure, industry, businesses and the environment," Mr Smith said in a statement.
   The minister said the DSE would on Thursday release Victoria's planned backburning for the next three years.

urn:contentItem:54XN-RXT1-JD34-V0K9-00000-00Israeli fined for massive Chile fire2012-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:24ZLexisNexisPg. 18Israeli fined for massive Chile fire

Israeli fined for massive Chile fire

SANTIAGO . An Israeli citizen accused of negligence which started a massive forest fire in a Chilean national park in Patagonia has reached an agreement in court to pay a $US10,000 fine and to perform two years community service.

The court in Puerto Natales, 3,200 km south of Santiago, approved the agreement with Israeli national Rotem Singer , who was suspected of setting toilet paper on fire that led to a fire which destroyed some 14,000 hectares of a national park forest.

Whales stressed by ship noise

BOSTON . Researchers say an ocean experiment that was accidentally conducted amid the shipping silence after the September 11, 2001, terror attacks has shown the first link between underwater noise and stress in whales.

The analysis showed a drop in the stress-related hormone in right whales following the attacks.

SMOKE from a massive forest fire in Arizona has reached the neighbouring state of New Mexico, prompting health officials to warn residents about potential respiratory hazards.

The 1080km blaze was no longer just an Arizona problem yesterday as firefighters moved to counter spot fires sprouting up across the state line, lighting their own fires to beat it back.

The fire remained largely uncontained and officials worried that the return of gusty southwesterly winds could once again threaten small mountain communities that had been largely saved just a few days ago.

Levels of tiny, sooty particles from the smoke in eastern Arizona were nearly 20 times the federal health standard yesterday.

More than 30 homes have been destroyed since the fire began May 29 and thousands of residents have fled their homes.
